description: figure seated in dhyanasana with hands in lap; cushion below figure carved with foliate sprays and central quatrefoil medallion; crest ornamented with a diamond-shaped srivatsa; back uncarved
inscription:
Carved inscription:

\"This image was caused to be made in samvat 1165 in the dark half of the month Jyestha, 5th day, a Wednesday, by Jaluka, son of Avasara ?, in the poravata lineage from which the poet Malli Kavi came.\"

Translation by Phyllis Granoff via email, 4/23/2014
markings: inscription on cushion at top; dealer\'s sticker, at proper left shoulderblade
text: The highly polished surface of this seated, meditative figure is a metaphor for his absolute purity. He is a Jina, or Tirthankara, a liberated being whose renunciation of passion and anger is intended to guide other individuals towards a life of nonviolence and respect for all living things. Devotees can choose to either remain in everyday life, or to practice austerities to free the soul from bondage. The Sanskrit inscription on the cushion names the patron of the sculpture and gives the date of its dedication to the Jain temple.
title: Seated Jina
